content: Florida Equine ID Cards for Intrastate and Interstate Movement

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The Division of Animal Industry of the Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services is now offering laminated cards, containing digital pictures of the horse, as a voluntary alternative to the current paper EIA test document (VS Form 10-11) and the Equine Event Extension. There are two types of cards available:

tag: html body text div div div ol li strong span
content: The Negative EIA Test Verification Card

tag: html body text div div div ol li span
content: will be accepted as proof of a negative EIA test within the state of Florida. The card has the same expiration date as the VS form 10-11 (coggins form). This card is

tag: html body text div div div ol li strong span
html body text div div div ol li span
content: valid for change of ownership, only the original VS form 10-11 or certified lab copy of the VS form 10-11 (coggins form) can be used for this purpose.

tag: html body text div div div ol li strong span
html body text div div div ol li span
content: will be accepted by participating states as proof of a negative EIA test and an Official Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (OCVI) within the previous six months, for interstate movement to equine events. This card is intended for the owner who frequents equine events in participating states. When traveling the OCVI and EIA do

tag: html body text div div div ol li strong span
html body text div div div ol li span
content: need to accompany the Passport Card as it contains the OCVI, EIA, owner and veterinarian information. This card is

tag: html body text div div div ol li strong span
html body text div div div ol li span
content: valid for change of ownership, only the original VS form 10-11 or certified lab copy of the VS form 10-11 can be used for this purpose.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The Equine Event Extension is a paper document which has been used in the past, and will still be offered by the State of Florida. The Event Extension, like the Passport Card, acts as an extension of the OCVI from 30 days to 6 months. For interstate travel, using the Equine Event Extension, the OCVI, current EIA and Event Extension document must be carried.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The states currently honoring the Florida Equine Passport Card and the Equine Event Extensions are:

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
content: Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p span
content: The Division of Animal Industry is now charging a fee of $10 for the first horse on the

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: application and $5 for each additional animal included on the same application. The

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: will be $5 per card and the

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: will carry a fee of $15 for the first horse on the application and $5 for each additional animal listed on the same application.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Requests for applications or questions about the Equine Cards can be made through our Bartow office by contacting Dr. John Irby, Bob Crawford Building, 605 E. Main St., Bartow, Florida 33830-4831, (863)519-8507 or by contacting the Tallahassee office at, 407 South Calhoun Street, Room 331 Mayo Building, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0800, (850)410-0900 or by e-mailing to

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: . Applications can be requested and digital images taken by individuals or veterinarians. The digital pictures required for the equine cards are the entire left side, entire right side and front view of the entire head. Each view should have approximately 10% background bordering all 4 sides of the image. The pictures for the equine cards can be submitted on a CD to our Bartow office with a completed application.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services is now participating in the USDA sponsored National Animal Identification System (NAIS). Anyone requesting a Florida Equine Card will be required to register the location where their horse resides. For more information on the National Animal Identification System you may log on to

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: . If you have questions regarding the NAIS please email the Department at
